Catherine kept her voice low but clear, aware that every word would be overheard and analyzed by the curious crowd. The foundation's reputation preceded her in most working-class areas of the city, though reactions to her charitable work varied widely depending on past experiences with well-meaning but ineffective reformers.

The proprietor's demeanor shifted subtly, suspicion giving way to cautious cooperation. "Ah, the Whitworth Foundation, yes. You've done good work for the families hereabouts, I'll grant you that. Mary's in the back corner there, though I should warn you she's been drinking steady since she arrived. The poor woman's beside herself with worry, and liquor's the only thing what helps her sleep anymore."

Catherine followed the woman's gesture to a dimly lit corner where a figure sat hunched over a glass, seemingly oblivious to the activity around her. Mary Kellison appeared to be in her forties, though hardship and grief had aged her beyond her years. Her dark hair was streaked with premature gray, and her clothes, while clean, showed the careful mending that spoke of careful management of limited resources. She looked up as Catherine approached, her eyes struggling to focus through the haze of alcohol and sorrow.

"Mrs. Kellison? I am Lady Catherine Forster. I believe we share a common interest in discovering what has happened to several missing young men, including your son." Catherine settled herself carefully in the opposite chair, noting how the woman's hands trembled as she reached for her glass. The table was scarred and stained from years of use, sticky with spilled drinks and marked with the initials of countless patrons seeking to leave some small mark of their existence.

"My boy... my poor boy Danny." Mary's voice was thick with drink and tears. "Good lad, he was, never gave me trouble like some. Worked hard at the docks, brought home his wages regular, helped with his younger sister's schooling. Then one night he just... gone. Like he never existed at all." She took another drink, her hand shaking so badly that liquid sloshed over the rim. "The constables, they took down particulars and promised to investigate, but that was six weeks ago and I've heard nothing since."

Catherine withdrew her notebook again, though she kept it partially concealed to avoid drawing additional attention from the other patrons. "Can you tell me about the circumstances of Daniel's disappearance? Was there anything unusual about that day, anyone new he might have encountered, any change in his normal routine?"

"He'd been working late shifts at the canal loading coal barges. Hard work, but it paid better than the mills, and we needed every penny with winter coming on." Mary wiped her eyes with a handkerchief that had seen better days. "That last night, he mentioned seeing someone asking questions about the workers, someone who didn't belong in that area. Big fellow, Danny said, unnaturally large and somehow wrong-looking. Made the other men nervous just being around him."

The description matched what the old woman in the alley had told her about the mysterious Preston. Catherine felt her pulse quicken as the pattern began to emerge more clearly. "Did Daniel mention anything specific about this man's questions? What exactly was he trying to learn about the workers?"

"Personal things, Danny said. Not about work or wages like you'd expect from someone looking to hire men. This fellow wanted to know about their families, their living situations, whether they had people who would miss them if they disappeared." Mary's voice dropped to barely above a whisper, and she glanced around nervously as if afraid of being overheard. "Danny thought it was strange enough to mention to his foreman, but the man just laughed and said there were always odd characters around the docks looking for one thing or another."

Catherine made careful notes while maintaining an expression of calm attention, though internally her alarm was growing. The methodical nature of the questioning suggested someone selecting victims based on specific criteria – young men with few social connections who might disappear without generating significant official interest. It was the behavior of a predator operating with disturbing calculation and confidence.

"Has anyone else reported similar encounters with this individual? Have there been other families dealing with unexplained disappearances?" Catherine asked, though she suspected she already knew the answer based on her earlier conversation. The pattern was becoming clearer, and it suggested something far more organized and sinister than random criminal opportunism.

"Three other families that I know of, though there may be more who haven't spoken up out of fear or shame." Mary finished her drink and signaled for another, ignoring Catherine's concerned look. "We've tried to share information among ourselves since the authorities don't seem inclined to take our concerns seriously. Young men from working families don't generate the same level of official interest as missing persons from more prominent households, if you take my meaning."

The bitter truth of Mary's observation was one that Catherine had encountered repeatedly in her charitable work. Justice in Manchester, as in most cities, operated according to social hierarchies that valued some lives far more than others. The disappearance of a merchant's son would mobilize significant resources, while working-class victims often received perfunctory attention at best before their cases were quietly forgotten or dismissed.

"I want you to know that I take these disappearances very seriously, and I intend to use whatever influence I possess to ensure proper investigation." Catherine reached across the table to place her hand gently over Mary's trembling fingers. "But I need you to help me understand everything you've learned about this pattern. Any detail, no matter how seemingly insignificant, might prove crucial in stopping whatever is happening to these young men."

**Chapter 2**

Mary's second drink arrived with practiced efficiency, the serving girl navigating through the crowded room with the skill born of years dodging the grasping hands and crude comments that were occupational hazards in such establishments. The interruption gave Catherine a moment to observe the other patrons more carefully, noting how several seemed to be listening to their conversation despite their apparent focus on their own companions. The atmosphere in the Seven Stars had shifted subtly since her arrival, the usual boisterous energy replaced by something more cautious and watchful, as if her presence had reminded everyone of dangers that were better left unspoken.

"There's something else you should know about this Preston fellow, though it may sound like the ravings of a grief-stricken mother," Mary continued after taking a steadying gulp from her fresh glass. "My Danny, he had a way with words, always did well in school before he had to leave for work. The night before he disappeared, he came home excited about something, said he'd been offered a position that would pay better than dock work and wouldn't break his back before he turned thirty. Someone had approached him about writing work, copying documents and keeping records for a gentleman who needed discretion in his business affairs."

Catherine felt a chill that had nothing to do with the drafts seeping through the building's ill-fitted windows. The old woman's earlier words about Preston keeping journals echoed in her mind, suggesting connections that painted an increasingly disturbing picture. "Did Daniel mention where this work was to take place, or provide any details about the nature of the documents he would be copying?"

"He was meant to meet the gentleman the next evening at a warehouse near Castlefield, one of those buildings that's been empty since the textile trade moved to newer facilities," Mary replied, her voice growing stronger as she focused on the details that might help explain her son's fate. "Danny was clever with letters and numbers, you see, much cleverer than most lads from our circumstances. He'd taught himself to read properly from books he borrowed, and his handwriting was fine enough for clerical work. The offer seemed like an answer to prayers, a chance to escape the kind of backbreaking labor that killed his father at forty-five."

The manipulation was elegant in its cruelty, Catherine realized. Preston, or whoever was orchestrating these disappearances, had identified not just vulnerable targets but had crafted approaches that would appeal to their specific circumstances and aspirations. The promise of better work, of escape from grinding poverty, would be irresistible to young men trapped by economic circumstances beyond their control. It suggested someone with considerable insight into the psychology of the working poor, someone who understood exactly which buttons to press to overcome natural caution.

"Mrs. Kellison, have you visited this warehouse? Did you attempt to investigate the location where Daniel was supposed to meet his potential employer?" Catherine kept her voice gentle, aware that her questions might be probing wounds that had barely begun to heal. The woman's pain was evident in every gesture, every tremor of her voice, and Catherine found herself struggling with the familiar tension between the need for information and the desire to offer comfort to those who had already suffered too much.

"I went there the morning after he failed to come home, though I knew in my heart that something terrible had happened," Mary replied, staring into her glass as if seeking answers in its amber depths. "The building was locked up tight, windows boarded over, no signs of recent occupation. I asked the watchman at the nearby goods yard, and he said no one had been using that particular warehouse for months. Either my Danny was given false information, or something happened to him before he could even reach the supposed meeting place."

The methodical nature of the deception suggested planning and resources that went well beyond the capabilities of a common criminal. Someone had taken the trouble to research potential victims, craft individualized approaches, and select locations that would minimize the risk of discovery or interference. It was the work of someone operating with confidence born of either extensive experience or powerful protection, possibly both.

Catherine was about to ask another question when she became aware of a subtle change in the atmosphere around them. The background noise of conversation and laughter had diminished noticeably, and several patrons were glancing toward the entrance with expressions of unease. She turned to follow their gaze and felt her breath catch in her throat as she saw the figure filling the doorway of the Seven Stars.

The man was enormous, easily approaching seven feet in height but hunched forward as if attempting to minimize his imposing presence. His shoulders were so broad they seemed to brush the door frame, and his hands, which hung at his sides like slabs of meat, were large enough to encircle a man's throat with room to spare. But it was his face that truly disturbed her, a collection of features that seemed assembled rather than naturally formed. His eyes were set too deep in his skull, creating shadows that made it difficult to discern their color or expression. His nose was small and delicate, absurdly inadequate for the massive skull that housed it, while his mouth stretched wider than human anatomy should have allowed.

"Sweet Mary and Joseph," whispered Mary Kellison, her face draining of color as she gripped Catherine's arm with surprising strength. "That's him. That's the man Danny described, the one who was asking questions at the docks."

Preston, for Catherine was certain this could be no one else, surveyed the room with the calm confidence of a predator assessing potential prey. His gaze lingered on various patrons, and she noticed how conversations died and eyes were averted wherever his attention fell. The proprietor approached him with obvious reluctance, her earlier assertiveness replaced by nervous deference that suggested this was not his first visit to the establishment.

"Good evening, Mr. Preston," the woman said, her voice barely carrying over the subdued murmur that had replaced the earlier animated conversation. "Will you be requiring your usual table this evening?"

"Indeed I will, Mrs. Hartwell, though I suspect I may have additional business to conduct before the night is through." Preston's voice was cultured and refined, the accent suggesting education and social position that seemed at odds with his disturbing appearance. His gaze swept the room again and seemed to linger for a moment on Catherine and Mary before moving on, though she could not be certain whether their scrutiny had been noticed.

Catherine felt every instinct screaming at her to leave immediately, to retreat to the safety of her carriage and the familiar world of proper society. But she also recognized that this might be her only opportunity to observe the man who seemed to be at the center of the disappearances that had brought her to this place. The proximity was terrifying, but it also offered the possibility of learning something that might help her understand what had happened to Daniel Kellison and the other missing young men.

"We need to leave," Mary whispered urgently, her earlier alcoholic haze burned away by fear so intense it was almost palpable. "He's seen us, I know he has. Danny always said there was something unnatural about how the man seemed to know things he shouldn't, as if he could read thoughts or see into people's souls."

Catherine was inclined to agree with Mary's assessment, but before she could respond, Preston began moving through the room toward their corner. He navigated between the tables with surprising grace for someone of his size, though she noticed how other patrons shrank away from him as he passed. The smell that the old woman had mentioned became apparent as he drew closer, a cloying sweetness like flowers left too long in stagnant water, underlaid with something else that made her stomach turn.

"Ladies," Preston said as he reached their table, his oversized mouth stretching into what might have been intended as a smile but resembled more closely a predator baring its teeth. "How delightful to encounter such refinement in these humble surroundings. I don't believe we've been properly introduced, though I confess I've heard a great deal about the charitable work of Lady Catherine Forster and her foundation."

The fact that he knew her identity sent a chill through Catherine that had nothing to do with the evening air seeping through the building's many gaps and cracks. She had not announced herself publicly, and her conversation with Mary had been conducted in deliberately low tones. Either he had been watching her longer than she realized, or he possessed sources of information that suggested connections extending far beyond what she had initially suspected.

"I'm afraid you have me at a disadvantage, sir," Catherine replied, forcing her voice to remain steady despite the fear that was making her hands tremble. "While you seem to know a great deal about me, I know nothing of you beyond your name, which I understand to be Preston."

"Indeed it is, though like many names, it represents only a portion of a larger truth." Preston's eyes, now that he was close enough for her to see them clearly, were an unusual pale blue that seemed almost colorless, and they held an intelligence that was somehow more disturbing than mere brutality would have been. "I understand you've been making inquiries about certain unfortunate disappearances among the working population. Such dedication to the welfare of the less fortunate is truly admirable, though I wonder if you fully understand the complexities of what you're investigating."

The veiled threat in his words was unmistakable, though delivered with the polished courtesy of a gentleman addressing equals at a social gathering. Catherine realized that she was facing someone far more dangerous than a simple predator driven by base appetites. This was a man of education and refinement who had chosen to use his advantages in the service of something fundamentally evil, someone whose very civility made his implied menace all the more chilling.

"I understand that young men are disappearing from the streets of Manchester, and that their families deserve answers about what has happened to their sons," Catherine replied, drawing on reserves of courage she wasn't entirely certain she possessed. "If you have information that might help resolve these mysteries, I would be grateful to hear it."

Preston's smile widened, revealing teeth that were white and perfectly formed but somehow too large for even his oversized mouth. "Oh, Lady Catherine, I have far more than mere information to offer. But such gifts require careful consideration and proper circumstances for their sharing. Perhaps you would be interested in visiting my private study, where we could discuss these matters away from the curious ears that seem to populate establishments such as this one."

Mary Kellison let out a strangled gasp at Preston's invitation, her grip on Catherine's arm becoming painful in its intensity. The offer hung in the air between them like a physical presence, and Catherine could feel the attention of the entire room focused on their exchange despite the studied attempts of the other patrons to appear occupied with their own affairs. The silence stretched uncomfortably, broken only by the distant sounds of industrial machinery that never truly ceased in Manchester's working districts and the nervous shuffling of feet as people tried to position themselves closer to the exits without appearing to flee.

Catherine understood that this moment represented a crucial decision point in her investigation. Accepting Preston's invitation would almost certainly place her in mortal danger, but it might also provide the only opportunity to learn what had happened to the missing young men and potentially prevent future disappearances. Declining might preserve her immediate safety but would leave the mystery unsolved and other vulnerable individuals at risk. The weight of responsibility pressed down upon her as she considered the implications of either choice, aware that her decision would have consequences extending far beyond her personal welfare.

"Your offer is most generous, Mr. Preston, but I'm afraid I must decline," Catherine replied carefully, noting how his pale eyes seemed to darken at her refusal. "My driver is waiting, and I have other appointments this evening that cannot be postponed. Perhaps we might arrange a more formal meeting at a mutually convenient time and location." She was proud that her voice remained steady despite the terror that was making her heart race and her palms sweat beneath her gloves. The social conventions of polite refusal felt absurdly inadequate in the face of what she suspected was a predator's invitation to become his next victim.

Preston's expression shifted subtly, the veneer of gentleman's courtesy cracking slightly to reveal something cold and calculating beneath. He straightened to his full imposing height, and Catherine was reminded of how a cat might stretch before pouncing on its prey, all fluid motion and barely contained violence. The other patrons of the Seven Stars seemed to sense the change in atmosphere, conversations dying completely as everyone waited to see how this unexpected confrontation would resolve itself.

"How disappointing," Preston said, his cultured voice carrying undertones of menace that made several nearby drinkers reach nervously for their coats. "I had hoped that someone of your evident intelligence and dedication would be more... adventurous in pursuit of the truth you claim to seek. But perhaps I misjudged your commitment to the welfare of those unfortunate young men whose fates seem to concern you so deeply." The implication was clear: her refusal to accompany him demonstrated either cowardice or lack of genuine care for the missing persons she purported to help.

Catherine recognized the manipulation for what it was, an attempt to goad her into reckless action by challenging her courage and dedication. She had encountered similar tactics from various unsavory characters during her years of charitable work, though never delivered with such polished sophistication or backed by such obvious physical menace. The key was to maintain her position without allowing pride or guilt to override prudent caution.

"I assure you, Mr. Preston, that my commitment to discovering the truth about these disappearances is absolute," Catherine responded, rising from her chair with as much dignity as she could manage while her knees threatened to buckle from fear. "However, I have learned through experience that hasty decisions often produce unfortunate consequences. I prefer to proceed methodically, gathering information from multiple sources before drawing conclusions or taking decisive action." She helped the trembling Mary Kellison to her feet, noting how the woman seemed barely able to stand despite her obvious desperation to flee the premises.

Preston watched their preparations to leave with an expression of amused contempt that was somehow more unsettling than open hostility would have been. He seemed entirely confident that this temporary setback would not significantly impede whatever plans he had been formulating, as if their escape was merely a minor inconvenience rather than a genuine obstacle to his intentions. The casual nature of his acceptance suggested resources and capabilities that extended far beyond what she had initially imagined.

"Of course, Lady Catherine, methodical investigation has its merits," Preston agreed with exaggerated politeness, stepping aside to allow them passage while remaining close enough that they would have to brush against his massive frame. "I do hope your inquiries prove fruitful, though I should caution you that some truths are more dangerous than the mysteries they replace. Manchester can be a treacherous city for those who delve too deeply into matters that are better left undisturbed."

The threat was delivered so smoothly and with such apparent civility that anyone overhearing might have mistaken it for friendly advice, but Catherine had no doubt about the genuine menace behind his words. Preston was warning her away from her investigation while simultaneously making it clear that he considered her activities to be under his observation. The implications were chilling, suggesting a level of confidence and organization that indicated either powerful protection or extensive experience in avoiding consequences for his actions.

Catherine guided Mary toward the exit with as much haste as dignity would allow, acutely aware of Preston's pale eyes following their progress across the crowded room. The other patrons parted before them like water, none willing to make eye contact or offer assistance, though she could see sympathy and concern in several faces. The atmosphere of fear that Preston's presence had created was palpable, transforming what should have been a refuge for working people into a trap where everyone felt vulnerable and exposed.

James was indeed waiting with the carriage, though Catherine could see the relief in his weathered features when they emerged from the Seven Stars more quickly than he had expected. His hand rested on the handle of a heavy walking stick that she knew concealed a sword blade, a precaution that now seemed far more prudent than paranoid. The elderly driver had served her family through various crises over the years, and his judgment regarding dangerous situations had proven reliable enough that she trusted his preparations implicitly.

"Home, James, with all possible speed," Catherine instructed as she helped the still-shaking Mary into the carriage. "But first, we need to deliver Mrs. Kellison safely to her residence." She glanced back at the Seven Stars and was disturbed to see Preston's massive silhouette filling one of the windows, watching their departure with the patient attention of a predator that knew it had successfully marked its prey. The sight sent another wave of cold fear through her, though she tried to maintain an appearance of calm for Mary's benefit.

The carriage rolled through Manchester's narrow streets with unusual urgency, James clearly as eager as his passengers to put distance between themselves and whatever threat Preston represented. The industrial landscape that surrounded them seemed more oppressive than usual in the gathering darkness, the endless rows of workers' housing and factory buildings creating a maze-like environment where pursuit or ambush could come from any direction. Catherine found herself studying every shadow and alleyway they passed, wondering if other eyes were tracking their progress through the night.

"He'll come for me next," Mary whispered, her voice barely audible over the clatter of wheels on cobblestones and the distant rumble of machinery that never ceased in Manchester's industrial heart. "He knows I've been asking questions, gathering information about the missing boys. I've made myself a target by trying to find out what happened to my Danny." Her hands shook so violently that she could barely maintain her grip on the leather strap that helped passengers maintain their balance during the carriage's motion through the uneven streets.

Catherine wanted to offer reassurance, to promise that Preston would not be allowed to harm anyone else, but she recognized that such assurances would be both hollow and potentially dangerous in their false comfort. The reality was that Preston clearly operated with impunity, confident enough in his safety to make barely veiled threats in a room full of witnesses. The authorities had already demonstrated their unwillingness or inability to investigate the disappearances seriously, and her own resources, while considerable, were not designed for confronting someone who combined physical menace with apparent social protection.

"Mrs. Kellison, I want you to consider temporarily relocating to safer accommodations," Catherine said carefully, aware that she was asking the woman to abandon her home and livelihood based on fears that might seem irrational to anyone who had not witnessed Preston's disturbing presence. "The Whitworth Foundation maintains several secure lodging houses for individuals facing extraordinary circumstances. You and your daughter would be welcome there while we work to resolve this situation."

Mary looked up with eyes that held a mixture of gratitude and despair, clearly torn between the practical impossibility of abandoning her life and the genuine terror that Preston had inspired. Her circumstances, like those of most working-class families, provided little flexibility for dramatic changes in living arrangements. She had employment responsibilities, financial obligations, and social connections that could not be easily transferred or abandoned without significant consequences.

"I appreciate your kindness, Lady Catherine, truly I do," Mary replied with the careful politeness of someone accustomed to navigating the complex social dynamics between different classes. "But I can't just disappear from my life any more than my poor Danny could. I've got work at the laundry that pays our rent, and my daughter's got her schooling to think about. Running away might keep us safe for a while, but it won't stop whatever's happening to other families, and eventually we'd have to return to face whatever consequences waited for us."

Catherine recognized the wisdom in Mary's analysis even as she feared for the woman's safety. The practical realities of working-class life left little room for the kind of dramatic gestures that wealth and social position made possible. Mary could not simply retreat to a country estate or hire private guards as Catherine herself might do when threatened. The very vulnerabilities that made working families attractive to predators like Preston also made it difficult for them to escape once they had been targeted.

The carriage reached Mary's modest lodgings in a narrow street lined with identical brick houses that had been hastily constructed to accommodate Manchester's growing industrial workforce. The buildings showed their age and the effects of industrial pollution, their original red brick now darkened to a grimy brown that seemed to absorb light rather than reflect it. Small windows glowed with the warm light of oil lamps and candles, creating a deceptively cozy atmosphere that concealed the overcrowding and poverty that characterized such neighborhoods.

"Promise me you'll be extremely careful," Catherine urged as Mary prepared to alight from the carriage. "Vary your routines, stay in well-populated areas, and trust your instincts if anything feels wrong. And please, send word immediately if you see or hear anything unusual. The foundation has resources that can be mobilized quickly if necessary." She pressed a card into Mary's hand along with several coins that would allow the woman to hire a messenger if circumstances required urgent communication.

Mary nodded gratefully, though Catherine could see in her expression the resignation of someone who understood that caution might delay but probably could not prevent whatever fate Preston had in mind for those who interfered with his activities. The woman straightened her shoulders with the kind of determined courage that Catherine had learned to associate with people who had survived hardships that would have destroyed more privileged individuals, and walked toward her door with steady steps despite the fear that was undoubtedly consuming her.

As the carriage pulled away from Mary's street, Catherine found herself grappling with the full implications of what she had learned during this evening's investigations. Preston was clearly far more than a simple predator operating opportunistically among Manchester's vulnerable population. His education, his apparent social connections, his confidence in his own immunity from consequences, and his methodical approach to selecting and manipulating victims suggested someone with extensive resources and experience. The missing young men were not random casualties but carefully chosen targets selected according to criteria that maximized his chances of success while minimizing the risk of serious investigation.

The challenge now was determining how to proceed with her investigation in the face of such obvious danger and apparent official indifference. Preston had made it clear that he was aware of her activities and considered her a potential threat to be neutralized rather than simply discouraged. At the same time, the scale and systematic nature of the disappearances suggested that without intervention, more young men would certainly vanish into whatever fate had claimed Daniel Kellison and the others.

Catherine settled back against the carriage's worn upholstery and began to formulate plans for the next phase of her investigation. She would need to approach Inspector Morrison with what she had learned, though she suspected that official channels would prove inadequate for addressing someone with Preston's apparent connections and resources. She would also need to take steps to protect both herself and the witnesses who had provided information, recognizing that her continued investigation would likely escalate the conflict with Preston rather than resolve it peacefully.

The carriage made its way through Manchester's darkening streets toward Catherine's estate, passing through neighborhoods that ranged from working-class respectability to genuine squalor before reaching the more prosperous areas where the city's merchant and professional classes maintained their residences. The contrast between different districts was stark, a reminder of the social and economic divisions that provided predators like Preston with convenient hunting grounds among those whose disappearances would generate minimal official concern.

As they approached the outskirts of the city, Catherine noticed that James was taking an indirect route home, frequently checking behind them and making unexpected turns that would reveal anyone attempting to follow their progress. The old driver's caution was probably wise, given Preston's demonstrated knowledge of her identity and activities, though she hoped that his interest would not extend to direct action against someone of her social position. Still, the events of the evening had made it clear that conventional assumptions about safety and social protection might not apply when dealing with someone as clearly dangerous and well-connected as the mysterious Preston appeared to be.

**Chapter 3**

The morning arrived with the kind of persistent drizzle that seemed to embody Manchester's industrial melancholy, droplets of moisture mixing with soot and smoke to create a fine gray mist that clung to windows and made the world appear as though viewed through dirty gauze. Catherine had slept poorly, her dreams populated by oversized figures with mismatched features stalking through endless mazes of factory buildings and workers' housing. She had awakened several times during the night with the certainty that someone was watching her estate, though each time she peered through her bedroom curtains she saw nothing but the familiar grounds and the reassuring presence of the groundskeeper making his regular rounds with a lantern and one of the estate's large mastiffs.

Over breakfast in her morning room, Catherine reviewed the notes she had compiled from the previous evening's investigations, attempting to organize the disturbing information into some coherent pattern that might suggest a course of action. The elegant surroundings of her home - the fine china, the carefully arranged flowers, the morning sunlight filtering through leaded glass windows - seemed to exist in a different world entirely from the grimy reality of the Seven Stars and the fear-haunted streets where Preston conducted his predatory activities. The contrast was jarring, a reminder of how easily those with wealth and position could insulate themselves from the harsh realities that defined existence for Manchester's working population.

Her contemplation was interrupted by the arrival of Inspector Morrison, whose early appearance suggested that he had taken her request for a meeting with unusual seriousness. Morrison was a career policeman who had worked his way up through the ranks by combining genuine competence with the political acumen necessary to navigate Manchester's complex web of civic and commercial interests. Catherine had found him to be more receptive to her concerns about social justice issues than many of his colleagues, though she suspected this was due as much to practical considerations about maintaining public order as to any deep commitment to equality or reform.

"Lady Catherine, I must confess that your message last evening intrigued me considerably," Morrison said as he accepted the tea and pastries that her housekeeper had prepared. The inspector was a man in his fifties with graying hair and intelligent eyes that missed little in their assessment of people and situations. His clothes were well-maintained but not expensive, marking him as someone who had achieved respectability through professional success rather than inherited advantages. "Your note mentioned discoveries related to the missing persons cases that have been reported in the industrial districts, though I should tell you frankly that we have little evidence to suggest these represent anything more than the usual migration of young men seeking better opportunities elsewhere."

Catherine set down her teacup with deliberate care, recognizing that Morrison's opening statement represented the kind of official skepticism she had expected to encounter despite his generally cooperative attitude toward her foundation's work. The police had limited resources and faced constant pressure to focus their attention on crimes that affected Manchester's more prominent citizens, making it understandable though frustrating that missing persons from working-class families would receive minimal investigation. Her challenge would be presenting the information she had gathered in terms that would compel official action despite the institutional biases that worked against such cases.

"Inspector Morrison, I appreciate your candor regarding the official assessment of these disappearances, but I believe the evidence suggests something far more sinister than simple migration," Catherine began, opening her notebook to the carefully organized observations from her investigation. "I have spoken with family members and witnesses who describe a systematic pattern of predatory behavior targeting vulnerable young men from the working population. The individual responsible appears to operate with considerable sophistication and confidence, suggesting either extensive experience or protection that places him beyond normal legal consequences."

Morrison's expression grew more serious as Catherine described her encounters with the old woman in the alley and Mary Kellison at the Seven Stars, though she could see him struggling to reconcile the dramatic nature of her account with his professional experience of more mundane criminal activities. The inspector took notes as she spoke, occasionally asking for clarification about specific details, but she sensed an underlying skepticism about the conclusions she was drawing from what he might consider insufficient evidence. The description of Preston, in particular, seemed to strain his credulity, as if the man's unusual physical appearance and brazen behavior were too theatrical to be entirely believable.

"Lady Catherine, the individual you describe is certainly distinctive enough that he should be known to our constables if he has been operating openly in the areas you mention," Morrison said thoughtfully, reviewing his own notes with the careful attention of someone accustomed to evaluating conflicting accounts and unreliable testimony. "However, I must point out that witness descriptions can be unreliable, particularly when influenced by grief, alcohol, or the kind of heightened emotions that missing persons cases naturally generate. People tend to remember encounters as more sinister in retrospect when they are seeking explanations for tragic events."

Catherine had anticipated this line of reasoning and was prepared with a response that addressed Morrison's professional concerns while emphasizing the urgency of the situation. She understood that police work required skepticism and careful evaluation of evidence, but she also recognized that official caution could become a form of institutional paralysis when dealing with crimes that fell outside normal patterns or targeted populations whose welfare was not considered a high priority by those in positions of authority.

"Inspector, I understand your caution regarding witness testimony, and under normal circumstances I would share your concerns about drawing dramatic conclusions from limited evidence," Catherine replied, maintaining the respectful but firm tone she had learned to use when advocating for her foundation's initiatives. "However, I had the opportunity to observe this Preston individual personally during my visit to the Seven Stars, and I can confirm that the witness descriptions were, if anything, understated rather than exaggerated. Moreover, his behavior during our brief encounter suggested someone who operates with complete confidence in his immunity from legal consequences, despite engaging in what amounted to barely veiled threats against potential witnesses."

The inspector's eyebrows rose at this revelation, and Catherine could see that her direct involvement in the investigation had elevated his assessment of the situation's seriousness. Morrison was experienced enough to recognize that members of the aristocracy did not typically involve themselves in dangerous criminal investigations without compelling reasons, and her willingness to venture into establishments like the Seven Stars suggested a level of concern that transcended mere charitable interest. At the same time, her personal exposure to potential danger would create political complications if anything happened to someone of her social prominence while pursuing what had been treated as routine missing persons cases.

"Lady Catherine, while I admire your dedication to the welfare of Manchester's working families, I must express serious concern about your direct involvement in what may indeed prove to be a dangerous criminal investigation," Morrison said with the careful diplomacy required when advising someone whose social position demanded respect even when her actions might be considered imprudent. "If this Preston individual is indeed responsible for the disappearances you've described, then your interference in his activities may have placed you at considerable personal risk. Such individuals do not typically distinguish between aristocratic and working-class victims when they perceive threats to their operations."

Catherine acknowledged the validity of Morrison's concerns while making it clear that she had no intention of abandoning her investigation simply to ensure her own safety. The inspector's warning was well-intentioned and probably accurate, but it also represented the kind of protective paternalism that had frustrated her throughout her years of charitable work. Men in positions of authority frequently assumed that women, particularly women of her social class, were incapable of making informed decisions about acceptable levels of risk in pursuit of important objectives.

"I appreciate your concern for my welfare, Inspector, but I must point out that several young men have already paid the ultimate price for society's failure to take these disappearances seriously," Catherine responded with steel in her voice that left no doubt about her determination to continue her investigation. "If my social position and resources can help bring attention to crimes that might otherwise be ignored, then I consider the personal risk to be an acceptable cost for potentially saving other lives. However, I would much prefer to work in cooperation with official law enforcement rather than conducting a parallel investigation that might complicate your efforts to apprehend the individual responsible."

Morrison studied her for a long moment, clearly weighing the political implications of various courses of action against his professional judgment about the most effective way to address the situation Catherine had described. The inspector was experienced enough to recognize that attempting to discourage her from further involvement would likely prove counterproductive, while her continued independent investigation might indeed complicate official efforts or place her in greater danger. At the same time, her social connections and resources could potentially provide advantages that normal police work might not achieve, particularly if the case involved individuals with wealth or political influence who might otherwise evade consequences for their actions.

"Very well, Lady Catherine, I propose a compromise that may serve both our interests while minimizing the risks to all concerned," Morrison said after careful consideration, his tone suggesting that he had reached a decision that satisfied his professional obligations while acknowledging the political realities of dealing with someone of her prominence and determination. "I will initiate a formal investigation into the missing persons cases you've identified, with particular attention to establishing the identity and background of this Preston individual. In exchange, I would ask that you share all information you gather through your own inquiries while refraining from direct confrontations that might escalate the situation or compromise the safety of yourself or potential witnesses."

Catherine recognized this as probably the best arrangement she could hope to achieve given the institutional constraints under which Morrison operated, though she had no intention of allowing official procedures to prevent her from pursuing leads that might prove time-sensitive. The inspector's willingness to take the case seriously represented significant progress from the previous official indifference, but she understood that police investigations moved slowly and often proved inadequate when dealing with individuals who possessed the resources and connections that Preston seemed to command. Her own investigation would need to continue, though perhaps with greater attention to the security precautions that Morrison's warnings had made seem increasingly prudent.

"I accept your proposal, Inspector, and I look forward to working together to resolve these disturbing cases," Catherine replied, though she made no specific commitments about limiting her own activities beyond avoiding unnecessary direct confrontations. "I should mention that I have already taken steps to protect some of the witnesses who provided information about Preston's activities, though I remain concerned about their long-term safety if this individual continues to operate with impunity. The fear among the working population is palpable, and it will likely worsen if more young men disappear while we are conducting our investigations."

Morrison nodded grimly, clearly understanding the broader implications of the situation Catherine had described. Public confidence in law enforcement depended partly on the perception that the authorities could protect ordinary citizens from predatory criminals, and failure to address systematic targeting of vulnerable populations could lead to the kind of social unrest that Manchester's civic and commercial leaders were always anxious to avoid. The inspector's career had been built on maintaining the delicate balance between different social groups that kept the city functioning despite its underlying tensions and inequalities.

"I share your concerns about public safety and confidence, Lady Catherine, which is why I intend to assign significant resources to this investigation despite the limited evidence currently available," Morrison assured her, though she suspected that his definition of "significant resources" might prove inadequate given the scale and sophistication of what they were confronting. "However, I must emphasize again the importance of caution in your own activities. If Preston is indeed responsible for multiple disappearances, then he has already demonstrated both the capability and willingness to eliminate those he perceives as threats to his operations. Your social position may provide some protection, but it would be unwise to rely entirely on conventional assumptions about the limitations such individuals typically observe."

Catherine thanked Morrison for his time and cooperation, though as she watched his carriage depart from her estate she found herself reflecting on the limitations of official law enforcement when confronting someone like Preston. The inspector was competent and well-intentioned, but he operated within a system designed to address conventional crimes committed by individuals who lacked the resources or connections to avoid consequences for their actions. Preston's apparent confidence and sophistication suggested someone who had learned to exploit the gaps and weaknesses in that system, making it unlikely that standard investigative procedures would prove sufficient to stop his predatory activities.

The remainder of the morning was devoted to correspondence related to her foundation's normal charitable activities, though Catherine found it difficult to concentrate on routine administrative matters while contemplating the implications of what she had learned about Preston's systematic targeting of Manchester's most vulnerable young men. The comfortable routine of managing soup kitchens, educational programs, and housing initiatives seemed almost trivial in comparison to the life-and-death stakes of her current investigation, though she recognized that all of her work was ultimately connected by the common goal of protecting those whom society's structures often failed to serve adequately.

Her reflections were interrupted by the arrival of an unexpected visitor, announced by her butler with the kind of carefully neutral expression that suggested either distinguished company or potentially unwelcome complications. Catherine was surprised to learn that Mr. Edmund Harwick, one of Manchester's most prominent textile manufacturers and a significant contributor to her foundation's activities, had arrived without appointment and requested an immediate audience on what he described as a matter of urgent mutual concern. Harwick's unannounced appearance was unusual enough to suggest that something significant had prompted him to abandon normal social protocols in favor of direct action.

Harwick was a man in his sixties who had built one of Manchester's largest textile operations through a combination of business acumen, political connections, and willingness to adapt quickly to changing market conditions. His relationship with Catherine had always been cordial but formal, based on their shared involvement in various charitable and civic initiatives rather than personal friendship. The manufacturer's support for her foundation had been generous but calculated, reflecting his understanding that strategic philanthropy could enhance his reputation while providing practical benefits for his business operations through improved community relations and worker loyalty.

"Lady Catherine, I apologize for the impropriety of arriving without notice, but I have learned of your recent investigations into certain disappearances among the working population, and I felt compelled to discuss the matter with you immediately," Harwick began without preamble, his usually composed demeanor showing signs of unusual stress and concern. The manufacturer's clothes were impeccable as always, but his face showed the effects of a sleepless night, and his hands trembled slightly as he accepted the refreshments her staff provided. "I have reason to believe that your inquiries may have brought you into contact with individuals whose activities pose dangers that extend far beyond what you might initially have suspected."

Catherine felt a familiar chill of apprehension as Harwick's words suggested that her investigation had attracted attention from quarters she had not previously considered. The manufacturer's obvious distress and his decision to abandon normal social conventions in favor of an urgent warning indicated that Preston's activities had implications reaching into Manchester's commercial and social elite. The prospect that her investigation might have uncovered something with tentacles extending throughout the city's power structure was both fascinating and terrifying in its potential ramifications.
